pros: Decent Benefit package, although not as good as it once was.  Plenty of room for moving up in the company or moving around the country via working at different hotels.  Discounted hotel rooms.

Marriott took great care of the managers and associate via training, departmental meetings, annual Town Hall meetings, good benefits and required training for managers every year.  All that is now gone.  Most of the hotels have cut the staffing almost in half ' do more with less' is now the guiding principle of the company. The pay is about the same as most of the big chains, depending on the city you are in.  Marriott won't pay the top wages, but they will be in the top 3-4.  Bottom line: good starting place, but plan to find better work as you get tired of working long hours, many days in a row, always understaffed and little to no recognition.  Sad what has happened to this once great company.

review_title: Headquarters: Solid, Mature Company; Good Work-Life Balance
pros:
At headquarters there is a strong company culture that is family friendly, with excellent work-life balance. Though it is a huge multinational company, there is still an underlying sense Marriott is a family-run operation: One still often sees Mr. Marriott himself in the cafeteria, and several top executives have Marriott in their names. 

It's mostly a 9-to-5 shop at MIHQ. Though obviously workload varies by department, there's generally a mass exodus from the building at 5:15 and no one bats an eyelash if you have to take your kid to soccer or work from home. 

With the Starwood merger there's good energy in the building, a sense that the company is growing and we're winning. There's a stable maturity to the business -- Marriott seems to know where it will be five, 10, 20 years from now.
cons:
Generally the pay at HQ is lower than competitors in the DC area. There's an overriding sense we're making 80 cents on the dollar in exchange for reasonable hours, good work-life balance and nice hotel discounts. Most seem comfortable with the trade-off, but you'll make less than your peers in most rank-and-file positions here. 

HQ itself is nice in the Hub and lobby; actual work spaces are beige cubicle farms. We're moving to a new downtown-Bethesda headquarters in 2022, but it's a long time to wait.

review_title: Courtyard by Marriott Front Desk Agent- DFW
pros: I absolutely loved the people I worked with, which was the only reason I stayed as long as i did. I typically did the AM shift so I was done by 3pm which was nice because I felt like I had the whole day open. The job duties are not super complex or difficult.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about the company itself or even the people who run it. However, the actual job itself was more than what I bargained for. Not that the job duties were difficult, but the constant dealing with complaints got old really quickly. There is always something for the guests to complain about, and most of the time it was about things we had no control over. Sometimes I would be working the PM shift (3-11pm) and would be the only employee in the building which made it hard to accommodate guest needs when you had to watch the front desk as well.

pros: I joined marriott as fresher, my joining experience was amazing, I worked at concierge, after 5-6 months I felt like I should change my department to service, I went to my departmental head spoke to him about the same, he was absolutely fine with the decision I made. review_title: Good pay/benefits, but don't go here for learning/development/advancement
pros:
Compensation (good pay, benefits, time off)
Discounted hotels.
cons:
Good ole boys corporate culture and resulting structure.
Compensation (leaving you in golden handcuffs/hard to make a move).
Lack of learning and advancement opportunities.

review_title: Doesn't like training or giving people chances
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Chicago, IL
pros: I have no pros for this company!
cons: This company is a disgrace to any workplace.. they deny everyone who applies to them who don't have the direct experience with the job that they are applying for. Marriott you do understand that people get into positions in the first place with someone believing and training a person to do the job correctly. If you don't have an extensive resume they deny you through email don't even give you the chance to interview. My friend had front Desk on his background & they hired him. I feel that's not fair because everyone has to start somewhere. I'll make sure none of my friends never stay at a Marriott owned hotel & I never will as well.

review_title: Enjoy the job, hate the management
pros: The job is relatively easy, and you get to meet a lot of interesting characters! I genuinely enjoy the job, it fits my outgoing personality a lot!
cons:
Schedules for the weeks, which start on Saturday, don't come out until the Wednesday beforehand! That gives you three (or less - sometimes it doesn't come til Thursday) days to know whether or not you can make plans for the weekend. This is the NUMBER ONE thing that if it changed - working here would be SO much more enjoyable.

Not to mention, the SEVERE hours cut. I was hired at full-time. I should stay at full time. Instead, during the winter months, I'm barely getting 30 hours a week! I had to get a second job to make up for it! I was never told that I was working seasonally when I was hired, so I shouldn't be treated as such!

job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Medford, MA
pros:
- Great weekly stand-up meetings  with regional team and leadership
- Employee discounts at select Marriott hotels (discount based on hotel room availability)
- Ability to shadow peers
- Open door policy with managers
- Networking opportunities with Marriott employees in other states
- Strong training program
cons:
- Mandated 50 hour work weeks
- Poor PTO flexibility 
- High quarterly revenue goals with little room to earn bonuses (no commission available either)
- Outdated corporate ideals in upper leadership
- Very high-pressure sales environment ("3 strikes and you're out" type deal- even in slower seasons)
- Very little work/life balance
- Upper management did not seem to care about employee well-being- everything seemed to be about hitting revenue goals
- Poor compensation considering Sales Managers were required to work 50 hours of week (sometimes more during busy season)

job_title: Front Desk Agent in London, England
pros:
The culture at the Marriott is next to nothing you'll experience.
They provide you with a free dinner, lunch or breakfast depending on your shift.
If you finished finished after your shift and tubes had stopped working they covered most of your taxi cost. 
You got good perks like big discounts of other Marriott hotels.
You could get a lot of experience for an entry level role into finance, sales & marketing and HR. You would never get that sort of experience at another starter level job.
cons:
The hours are are anti-social and you have to really like serving the guest and being in hospitality.
The Marriott rewards system means that guests can be even more confrontational with you, especially if they are gold or above.
